div.head: To the READER.
div.p: AS one de≈øirous of nothing more then the publike good, I here mo≈øt willingly impart vnto thee (Gentle Reader) that which by my own experience I finde in regard of the benefit it affoords, worthy thy paines and ob≈øeruatioÃÑ. It hath plea≈øed his Maie≈øtie out of his deepe di≈øcerning iudgemeÃÑt, to giue my purpo≈øe a ≈øpecial approbatioÃÑ & withal to expre≈øse a willingne≈ø≈øe in him≈øelfe to further ≈øo good a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe as by his gratious Letters hereunto annexed mo≈øte manife≈øtly appeares. Accept therefore of the≈øe my briefe directions, & approoue of them as they prooue: I could haue extended them to a farther length; but Oratorie needs not where the thing it ≈øelfe per≈øwades: Yet ≈øome peraduenture that haue laboured in the like before, will take occa≈øion to countenance them≈øelues & make my breuitie an argument of vn≈øufficiency, although I hope they will con≈øider that a Kings Picture may bee as perfect in a penny as in the large≈øt coine.

And what≈øoeuer hath beene by them publi≈øhed, interpreting other mens workes, according to the practi≈øe thereof in Forraigne parts, where the ≈øame as yet is generally better vnder≈øtood, I doubt not but future tryall will verifie this my booke to be euerie way heere more corre≈øpondent to the creature whereof it treates: and for ≈øuch I commend it to each vnpartiall vnder≈øtanding.

div.p:
IT is a principall part of that Chri≈øtian care which appertaineth to ≈øoueraigntie, to endeauour by all meanes po≈øsible, a≈øwell to beget as to increa≈øe among their people the knowledge and practi≈øe of all Artes and Trades, whereby they may be both wained from idlene≈ø≈øe & the enormities therof, which are infinite, and exerci≈øed in ≈øuch indu≈øtries and labours, as are accompained with euident hopes, not onely of pre≈øeruing people from the ≈øhame and greefe of penuire, but al≈øo of ray≈øing and increa≈øing them in wealth and aboundance, The ≈øcope which euerie freeborne ≈øpirit aymeth at, not in regard of him≈øelfe onely and the ea≈øe which a plentiful e≈øtate bringeth to euerie one in his particuler, but al≈øo in regard of the honor of their natiue country, who≈øe
commendations is no waie more ≈øet foorth then in the peoples actiuenes and indu≈øtrie. The con≈øideration whereof hauing of late occupied our minde, who alwaies e≈øteeme our peoples good our nece≈ø≈øarie contemplations, we haue coÃÑceiued as well by the di≈øcour≈øe of our owne rea≈øon, as by information, gathered from others, that the making of ≈øilke might as well be effected heere as it is in the kingdome of France, where the ≈øame hath of late yeares beene put in practi≈øe: For neither is the clymate of this Ile ≈øo far di≈øtinct or different in condition from that countrie, e≈øpecially froÃÑ the hither parts therof, but that it is to be hoped that tho≈øe things which by indu≈øtry pro≈øper there, may by like indu≈øtrie v≈øed heere haue like ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: and many priuate per≈øons who for their plea≈øure haue bred of tho≈øe wormes, haue found no experience to the contrarie, but that they may be nouri≈øhed and maintained heere if proui≈øion were made for planting of Mulberie trees, who≈øe leaues are the food of the Wormes. And therefore wee haue thought good hereby to let you vnder≈øtand, that although in ≈øuffering this inuention to take place, we doe ≈øhew our ≈øelues ≈øomewhat an aduer≈øary to our profit, which in the matter of our Cu≈øtomes for ≈øilk brought from beyond the Seas, will receiue ≈øome deminution: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, when there is que≈øtion of ≈øo great and publique vtilitie to come to our kingdome
and ≈øubiects in generall, and whereby (be≈øides multitudes of people of both ≈øexes and all ages) ≈øuch as in regard of impotencie are vnfitte for other labour, may bee ≈øet on worke, comforted and releeued; We are content that our priuate benefit ≈øhall giue way to the publique, and therefore beeing per≈øwaded that no well affected Subiect will refu≈øe to put his helping hand to ≈øuch a work as can haue no other priuate end in vs, but the de≈øire of the wel-fare of our people, we haue thought good in this forme onely to require you (as a per≈øon of greate≈øt authoritie within that Countie) and from whome the generalitie may receiue notice of our plea≈øure (with more conueniencie them otherwi≈øe) to take occa≈øion either at the quarter Se≈øsions, or at ≈øome other publique place of meeting, to per≈øwade and require ≈øuch as are of abilitie (without di≈øcending to trouble the poore, for whome we ≈øeeke to prouide) to buye and di≈øtribute in that Countie, the number of ten thou≈øand Mulberie plants, which ≈øhal be deliuered vnto them at our Cittie of &c, at the rate of three farthinges the Plant; or at ≈øixe ≈øhillings the hundred, containing fiue-≈øcore plants. And becau≈øe the buying of the ≈øaid Plants at this rate, may at fir≈øt ≈øeeme chargeable to our ≈øaid ≈øubjects, (whome we would bee loath to burthen) wee haue taken order, that in March or Aprill next, there ≈øhall be deliuered at
the ≈øaide place a good quantitie of Mulberie-≈øeedes, there to be ≈øold to ≈øuch as will buy them, By meanes whereof the ≈øaid plants will bee deliuered at a ≈ømaller rate them they can be afforded being caried from hence: hauing re≈øolued al≈øo in the meane time that there ≈øhall bee publi≈øhed in print a plaine In≈øtruction and direction, both for the encrea≈øing of the ≈øaide Mulberie-trees, the breeding of the Silke-worms, & all other thinges needefull to be vnder≈øtood, for the perfecting of a work euery way ≈øo coÃÑmendable & profitable as wel to the planter as to tho≈øe that ≈øhal v≈øe the trade; Hauing now made knowne vnto you the motiues as they ≈øtaÃÑd, with the publik good, wherin euerie man is intere≈ø≈øed, becau≈øe wee knowe how much the example of our owne Deputie-Lieuetenants and Iu≈øtices, wil further this cau≈øe, if you and other your neighbours wil be content to take ≈øome good quaÃÑtities hereof, to di≈øtribute vpon your owne landes: wee are content to acknowledge thus much more in this direction of ours, that all thinges of this nature tending to plantations, increa≈øe of Science, and works of indu≈øtrie, are thinges ≈øo naturally plea≈øing to our owne di≈øpo≈øition, as wee ≈øhall take it for an argument of extraordinarie affection towards our per≈øon, be≈øides, the iudgement we ≈øhall make of the good di≈øpo≈øitions in all tho≈øe that ≈øhall expre≈ø≈øe in any kinde their ready mindes, to further
the ≈øame, And ≈øhal e≈øteeme that in furthering the ≈øame, they ≈øeeke to further our honour and contentment, who hauing ≈øeene in few yeares ≈øpace pa≈øt, that our Brother the French King hath ≈øince his comming to that Crowne, both begun and brought to perfection the making of Silkes in his countrie, whereby he hath wonne to him≈øelf honour, and to his ≈øubiects a meruailous increa≈øe of wealth, would account it no little happines to vs, if the ≈øame worke which wee begun among our people with no le≈ø≈øe zeale to their good (then any Prince can haue to the good of theirs) might in our time produce the fruits which there it hath done; wherof we nothing doubt if ours will be found as tractable and apt to further their owne good, now the way is ≈øhewed them by vs their Soueraigne, As the≈øe of France haue bene to conforme them≈øelues to the directions of their King.

div.head: INSTR∆≤CTIONS For the increa≈øe and planting of Mulberie Trees.
VVhat ground is fit for the Mulberie ≈øeedes, how the ≈øame is to be ordered, & in what ≈øort the ≈øeedes are to be ≈øowed therein.
div.p: THE ground which ought to be appointed for this purpo≈øe, be≈øides the naturall goodne≈ø≈øe of it, mu≈øt be rea≈øonably well dunged, and withall ≈øo ≈øcituated, as that the heate of the ≈øunne may cheri≈øh it, and the nipping bla≈øtes of either the North winde or the Ea≈øt, may not annoy it: the choice thereof thus made, that the ≈øeeds may the better pro≈øper, & come vp after they bee ≈øowne, you ≈øhal dig it two foote deepe, breaking the clods as ≈ømall as may be, and afterward you ≈øhall deuide the ≈øame into ≈øeuerall Beds of not aboue fiue foote in breadth, ≈øo that you ≈øhal not neede to indanger the plants by treading vpon them, when either you water or weede them.

The Mulberie ≈øeedes you ≈øhall lay in water for the ≈øpace of xxii houres, and after that you ≈øhall drye them againe halfe drie, or ≈øomewhat more, that when you ≈øowe them they may not cleaue together: Thus done, you mu≈øt ca≈øt them vppon the fore ≈øaide beds, not altogether ≈øo thicke as you v≈øe to doe other
garden Seedes, and then couer them with ≈øome fine earth (pa≈øt thorough a Siue) about halfe an inch thicke: In drye weather you ≈øhall water them euerie two daies at the farthe≈øt, as likewi≈øe the Plants that ≈øhall come of them; and keepe them as cleane from weedes as po≈ø≈øibly you can.

The time in which you ought to ≈øowe them for your be≈øt aduantage, is either in March, Aprill, or May, when fro≈øtes are either altogether pa≈øt, or at the lea≈øt not ≈øo ≈øharpe, or of ≈øo long continuance, as to indanger their vp≈øpring.

There is yet another way to ≈øowe them, and that is as followeth: you ≈øhall (being directed by a ≈øtraite line) make certaine furrowes in the beds aboue mencioned of ≈øome foure fingers deepe, and about a foot in di≈øtance the one from the other: After this, you ≈øhall open the earth with your hands, on either ≈øide of the afore≈øaid Furrowes, ≈øome two fingers from the bottome, and where you haue ≈øo opened it, ≈øhall you ≈øowe your ≈øeedes; and then couer them halfe a finger thicke with the earth which before you opened.

div.head: VVhen the Plants that are ≈øprung vp of the ≈øeeds, are to bee remooued, and how they are to be planted the fir≈øt time.
div.p: IN the monethes of September, October, Nouember, December, March or Aprill, the next yeare after the ≈øeedes are ≈øowne, you may remooue their plants, (or in the month of Ianuarie, if it bee not in fro≈øtie weather) and ≈øet them in the like beds as before, and about one foote the one from the other, but fir≈øt you mu≈øt cut off their rootes about 8. inches in length, and their tops about halfe a foote aboue their roots, more or le≈ø≈øe, according to the ≈øtrength of the ≈øaide plants, for the weaker they be the le≈ø≈øe tops you ≈øhal leaue them. In this ≈øort you may ≈øuffer them to remaine (weeding and watering them as neede ≈øhall require) till they bee growne ≈øixe foote in length aboue their roots, whereunto when once they haue attained, you may cut their tops, and ≈øuffer them to ≈øpread, alwaies hauing a care to take away the many branches or ≈øuccours, that may any way hinder their growth, vntil they be come to their full length of ≈øixe foot, as a fore≈øaid.

div.head: VVhen, and how the Plants are to be remooued the ≈øecond time, and in what manner they are to bee planted where they ≈øhall remaine.
div.p: IN the Monethes afore≈øaid, (according as your plants are waxen ≈øtrong,) you may remoue them either into the hedges of your fields, or into any other grouÃÑds. If in hedges, you mu≈øt ≈øet them ≈øixeteene foote the one from the other, if in other grounde, intending to make a wood of them eighteene foote at the lea≈øt. But a month before you doe remooue them, you mu≈øt make the holes (wherein you purpo≈øe to ≈øet theÃÑ) about foure foot in breadth, and ≈øo deep as that their rootes may bee well couered, and ≈øome halfe a foote of loo≈øe earth left vnder them, hauing alwaies a ≈øpeciall care ≈øo to place them, that they may receiue the benefit of the Sunne, and not to be ≈øhadowed or ouer-≈øpred by any neighbouring trees.

div.head: VVhen, and how the egges of the Silke-wormes are to be hatched, and how to order the Wormes that ≈øhall come of them.
div.p: WHen the leaues of Mulberie trees begin a little to bud foorth, take the Egges of your Silke-wormes, and lay them in a peece of Say, or ≈øuch like ≈øtuffe, and in the day time carie them in ≈øome warme place about you, in a little ≈øafe Boxe, but in the night either lay them in your bed or betweene two warme pillowes, vntill ≈øuch time as the wormes begin to come foorth: then take a peece of paper of the widenes of the ≈øaid boxe, & hauing cut it full of ≈ømall hoales, lay in within the ≈øame vppon the Egges, and vppon that againe ≈øome fewe Mulberie leaues, to which the Wormes as they are hatched, will continually come. The≈øe leaues with the wormes vpon them, you mu≈øt ≈øtill remooue into other boxes, laying fre≈øh leaues a≈øwel on tho≈øe that are remooued as on the paper where the Egges are; and this is the cour≈øe which mu≈øt be duely kept and ob≈øerued, vntill ≈øuch times as all the wormes be come foorth of their ≈øhels, ≈øtill keeping their boxes warme: as afore≈øaide, but no longer about you, but vntill the wormes begin to come forthout of which boxes you may ≈øafely take them, when once they haue pa≈øt their ≈øecond ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and feede them vpon ≈øhelues of two foote in bredth, and eighteene inches one aboue the other, as in this figure following is expre≈ø≈øed.

figure.figDesc: depiction of feeding shelves for silk worms

div.p: The ≈øaid ≈øhelues are not to be place in any ground-roome, nor yet next vnto the Tyles, but in ≈øome middle roome of your hou≈øe which openeth vpon the North & ≈øouth, that you may the more conueniently giue them either heate or ayre, according as the time & ≈øea≈øoÃÑ ≈øhal require. Be≈øides, you mu≈øt not make them clo≈øe vnto the Walles but ≈øo as you may pa≈ø≈øe about them, the better to looke vnto the Wormes, & keepe them from Rats & Mice, which otherwi≈øe might deuoure them. You mu≈øt ob≈øerue the times of their comming foorth, and keepe euerie one or two daies hatching by them≈øelues, that you may the better vnder≈øtand their ≈øeuerall ≈øickne≈ø≈øes or ≈øleepings, which are foure in the time of their feeding. The fir≈øt commonly ≈øome twelue daies after they are hatched, and from that time at the end of euerie eight daies, according to the weather and their good or ill v≈øage: during which time of euery ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, which la≈øteth two or three daies, you mu≈øt feede them but verie little, as onely to releeue ≈øuch of them, as ≈øhall haue pa≈øt their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe before the re≈øt, and tho≈øe that ≈øhall not fall into their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe ≈øo ≈øoone.

The whole time that the wormes doe feede, is about nine weekes, whereof vntill they come vnto their fir≈øt ≈øickenes, giue them young Mulberie leaues twice euerie day, but few at a time; from thence vntil their ≈øecond ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, twice euerye day in greater quantity; and ≈øo from their ≈øecond to their third ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, increa≈øing the quantity of the leaues, according as you perceiue the wormes to grow in ≈øtrength, and cleare of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe: from the third vntill their fourth ≈øickne≈ø≈øe; you may giue them leaues thrice euery day
and the fourth being pa≈øt, you may let them haue ≈øo many as they will eate, alwaies hauing a care that you giue them none, but ≈øuch as are drie, and well ayred vpon a Table or cloath, before they be laid vpon them, and withal gathered ≈øo neere as may be, at ≈øuch times as either the ≈øunne or winde hath cleared them of the deaw that falleth vpon them.

For the feeding of Wormes you neede ob≈øerue no other order then this, lay the Mulberie leaues vppon them, and euerie two or three daies remooue them, and make cleane their boxes, or ≈øhelues, vnle≈ø≈øe in times of their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, for then they are not to bee touched: the leaues which you take from them when you giue theÃÑ fre≈øh to feed vpon, you mu≈øt lay in ≈øome conuenient place, and vpon them a few new leaues, to which the wormes that lay hidden in the old, wil come, & then you may pa≈ø≈øe them with the ≈øaid newe leaues to the re≈øt of the wormes: And now lea≈øt anye thing ≈øhould bee omitted, which ≈øerues to perfect the di≈øcouery of ≈øo excellent a benefit, I will adui≈øe you to bee very diligent in keeping cleane their Boxes, or Shelues, as being a ≈øpeciall meanes whereby to pre≈øerue them; wherfore when you intend to doe it; you ≈øhall remooue them together with the vppermo≈øte leaues wheron they lye, vnto other boxes or ≈øhelues, for with your haÃÑds you may not touch them, till they haue throughly vnder-gone their third ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and then may you pa≈ø≈øe them gently with cleane handes, without doing them any harme: prouided that the partie that commeth neare them ≈ømel not of garlick, onyons or the like. The fir≈øt fiue weekes of their age you mu≈øt be very carefull to keepe them warme, and
in time of raine or could weather, to ≈øet in the roome where they remaine, a pan with coales burning in it, now and then ≈øome Iuniper, Beniamin, and ≈øuch like, that yeeldeth ≈øweete ≈ømels. But afterwards, vnle≈ø≈øe in time of extraordinary cold, giue them ayre, and take heede of keeping them to hot, being alwaies mindefull to ≈øtore the roome with hearbes and flowers which are delightfull and plea≈øing to the ≈ømell. As the wormes increa≈øe in bigne≈ø≈øe, you ≈øhal di≈øper≈øe them abroad vpon more boardes, or ≈øhelues, and not ≈øuffer them to lie too thicke rogether, & if you finde any of them broken, or of a yellowe gli≈øtering collour inclining to ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, ca≈øt them away lea≈øt they infect the re≈øt, and ≈øort ≈øuch as are not ≈øicke, the greate≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt by them≈øelues, for ≈øo the le≈ø≈øer will pro≈øper the better.

div.head: When, and how to make fit roomes for the Wormes to worke their bottomes of ≈øilke in, and in what ≈øorte the ≈øaid bottomes are to be v≈øed.
